choices.C: Use Amazon Macie to identify the sensitive data. Create a set of AWS Lambda functions to remove the sensitive data.
choices.B: Deploy the model on an Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) cluster that uses AWS Fargate. Create an AWS Batch job to identify and remove the sensitive data.
choices.D: Use Amazon Comprehend to identify the sensitive data. Launch Amazon EC2 instances to remove the sensitive data.
choices.A: Deploy the model on Amazon SageMaker. Create a set of AWS Lambda functions to identify and remove the sensitive data.

questions.question_text:
A company uses a hybrid cloud environment. A model that is deployed on premises uses data in Amazon 53 to provide customers with a live conversational engine.
The model is using sensitive data. An ML engineer needs to implement a solution to identify and remove the sensitive data.
Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Macie: Automate processe helps in handle the sensitive data

Selected Answer: C
Macie - Identify sensitive data

Selected Answer: C
This is the purpose of Macie. Comprehend will work also for PII but that EC2...

questions.question_text:
An ML engineer needs to create data ingestion pipelines and ML model deployment pipelines on AWS. All the raw data is stored in Amazon S3 buckets.
Which solution will meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose is for real-time streaming ingestion, the question implies batch processing (raw data is in S3).

Selected Answer: B
Data ingestion - Glue ; Model deployment pipeline - sagemaker studio classic

Selected Answer: B
This is the main use-case for Glue.

choices.B: Use AWS Glue to create the data ingestion pipelines. Use Amazon SageMaker Studio Classic to create the model deployment pipelines.
choices.A: Use Amazon Data Firehose to create the data ingestion pipelines. Use Amazon SageMaker Studio Classic to create the model deployment pipelines.
choices.D: Use Amazon Athena to create the data ingestion pipelines. Use an Amazon SageMaker notebook to create the model deployment pipelines.
choices.C: Use Amazon Redshift ML to create the data ingestion pipelines. Use Amazon SageMaker Studio Classic to create the model deployment pipelines.

questions.question_text:
A company that has hundreds of data scientists is using Amazon SageMaker to create ML models. The models are in model groups in the SageMaker Model Registry.
The data scientists are grouped into three categories: computer vision, natural language processing (NLP), and speech recognition. An ML engineer needs to implement a solution to organize the existing models into these groups to improve model discoverability at scale. The solution must not affect the integrity of the model artifacts and their existing groupings.
Which solution will meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Because according to the documentation - 
"Any operation you perform on your Collections does not affect the integrity of the individual Model Groups they contain—the underlying Model Group artifacts in Amazon S3 and Amazon ECR are not modified."

Selected Answer: D
Option-D Any operation you perform on your Collections does not affect the integrity of the individual Model Groups they contain—the underlying Model Group artifacts in Amazon S3 and Amazon ECR are not modified.

Selected Answer: D
A could also be a valid option but in here we see exactly this:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/modelcollections.html
"Any operation you perform on your Collections does not affect the integrity of the individual Model Groups they contain—the underlying Model Group artifacts in Amazon S3 and Amazon ECR are not modified."

Selected Answer: D
I pick D. Creating custom tags for each of the three categories and adding them to the model packages in the SageMaker Model Registry (Option A) is a valid approach. However, it might not be as effective for organizing models at scale compared to using Model Registry collections.

choices.C: Use SageMaker ML Lineage Tracking to automatically identify and tag which model groups should contain the models.
choices.D: Create a Model Registry collection for each of the three categories. Move the existing model groups into the collections.
choices.A: Create a custom tag for each of the three categories. Add the tags to the model packages in the SageMaker Model Registry.
choices.B: Create a model group for each category. Move the existing models into these category model groups.

choices.C: Use SageMaker Model Monitor to evaluate the performance of the model and to manage the approval.
choices.B: Use SageMaker ML Lineage Tracking on the central model registry. Create tracking entities for the approval process.
choices.D: Use SageMaker Pipelines. When a model version is registered, use the AWS SDK to change the approval status to "Approved."
choices.A: Use SageMaker Experiments to facilitate the approval process during model registration.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The SageMaker Model Registry within the pipeline provides functionality to manually or programmatically approve models for production deployment.

Selected Answer: D
SageMaker Pipelines is designed to orchestrate machine learning workflows, including manual approval steps for model registration. You can define a step in the pipeline where a manual approval process is required before the model's status is changed to "Approved" for deployment.

Selected Answer: D
This tricked my as option D is not clearly worded:
A. No, SageMaker Experiments allows to track and organize your experiment but not for approving models
B. No, SageMaker ML Lineage Tracking allows to track model lineage but do not allow to approve a model
C. No, SageMaker Model Monitor allows to monitor data quality, model quality, bias and feature attribution
D. Yes, After you create a model version, you typically evaluate its performance and then update the approval status of the model version. You can update the approval status of a model version by using the SDK, SageMaker Studio console or with a condition step in a SageMaker AI pipeline

Selected Answer: D
The SageMaker Model Registry within the pipeline provides functionality to manually or programmatically approve models for production deployment.

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/en_us/sagemaker/latest/dg/model-registry-approve.html
"You can update the approval status of a model version by using the AWS SDK "

questions.question_text:
Case Study -
A company is building a web-based AI application by using Amazon SageMaker. The application will provide the following capabilities and features: ML experimentation, training, a central model registry, model deployment, and model monitoring.
The application must ensure secure and isolated use of training data during the ML lifecycle. The training data is stored in Amazon S3.
The company must implement a manual approval-based workflow to ensure that only approved models can be deployed to production endpoints.
Which solution will meet this requirement?

A company runs an Amazon SageMaker domain in a public subnet of a newly created VPC. The network is configured properly, and ML engineers can access the SageMaker domain.
Recently, the company discovered suspicious traffic to the domain from a specific IP address. The company needs to block traffic from the specific IP address.
Which update to the network configuration will meet this requirement?

choices.A: Create a security group inbound rule to deny traffic from the specific IP address. Assign the security group to the domain.
choices.C: Create a shadow variant for the domain. Configure SageMaker Inference Recommender to send traffic from the specific IP address to the shadow endpoint.
choices.D: Create a VPC route table to deny inbound traffic from the specific IP address. Assign the route table to the domain.
choices.B: Create a network ACL inbound rule to deny traffic from the specific IP address. Assign the rule to the default network Ad for the subnet where the domain is located.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
There is no deny in SG's - only allows- So NACL is the clear answer here

Selected Answer: B
Protection at subnet level: Network ACL. Specific IP addresses can be denied at inbound connection level

Selected Answer: B
That's basic network topic.

exam.name: AWS Certified Machine Learning Engineer - Associate MLA-C01
